content.text: Apogee Quick Start
Apogee is a tool to do quick, random programming tasks such as manipulating data or prototyping algorithms.

The benefits of using it are that you can program incrementally, seeing your progress as you go. There is also very little setup work, or other overhead for things like processing asynchronous functions or handling errors.
This page is live workspace that you can edit, so please make changes and experiment. You won't break anything.
Data Cell
This is similar to the cell in a spreadsheet. It can have a static value or it can have a formula. However, the static value is a JSON value. And the formula is a javascript function.

Here is a data cell with a static value. You can set a static value by typing it into the "data" view for the cell. It should be a proper json value, which can include a JSON Object, JSON Array, a string or a number.

Here is a data cell with a formula. You can set the formula by entering the body of a javascript function into the "code" view of the cell. The resulting value will be the return value of the function.
Note how in the formula can access the other cells as variables, using their name.
Also, try to change the values in
dummyArray
. The dependent cell
dummyProcessedArray
will automatically update.
Asynchronous Actions
If you want to do an asynchronous action, return a Promise. Below we make a web request using Fetch.
When you save this, you see a yellow banner. Any cell that depends on this will wait for the response.
TIP:

To handle the error we threw an error. Though some frown on this in normal javascript programming, here it is recommended - If we throw an error, downstream cells that depend on this will not attempt their calculation. If you don't throw an error they you have to handle the error case in all downstream cells. Besides, it is expected that you are programming here INTERACTIVELY and the error makes it very visible you need to fix that cell.
Now the we have data we can process it. Here we will calculate the percentage of the population that is male for each age.
NOTE:

It would be nice to chart this data to see how it varies. And you can, but check out another tutorial for this. If I did that here it would look like this is supposed to be a competitor to a Jupyter notebook. It is good for that, though currently the ecosystem here is very immature for now.
A good place to start with this tool is for quick and dirty calculations where you are manipulating data or prototyping algorithms.
TIP:

It would have been easy to append the "map" function in populationPercentageMaleByAge into populationDataRequest, which would often be done in normal javascript programming. Here it is recommended NOT to do that. Instead it is recommended to have MORE cells each with a simple fomula. This is so you can see feedback from each step as you go.
Other Types of Cells and Useful Components
There is also a
Function Cell

. You create it just like you would a data cell, but the code in it is the body of a function you can call from other cells, like you would expect. You can see more about this function and other functions in a tutorial.
Another basic component is a
Page
. This is not a cell, but it is another useful component. It forms a namespace. You create new pages from the panel on the left. You can see more about this in a tutorial.
In the left panel you can also add libraries, including modules, javascript files and css files.Again, this is covered in a tutorial.

The above features are the basic components to replicate most javascript programming here rather than in a text editor. There are however special cells you can use. This includes forms, custom UI elements, charts and, in theory at least, anything else you can imagine. Again, this is covered in another tutorial.
What to Do Now?
Edit this workspace and try things out.
There is also a valid population URL like the one above for the years 1980 and 2000.
Try an invalid URL
Make your own cells with your own formulas
